oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Doing the wash
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: An African American woman is pictured using a long pole to stir the laundry at the back of a multi-story dwelling. The laundry heats over a fire in a black iron kettle. The house, with clothes drying on the once-elegant porch rails, is visible behind her. A dinner bell is mounted on a structure at right.

Following the Civil War, African American women often found work as laundresses in white homes and hotels. Period censuses are filled with examples of black women identified as "laundress." There is even a statue of an African American laundress at a Union contraband camp in Corinth, Mississippi.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Earl S. Miers River Photograph Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Laundry; Domestic life; Laundresses; Housework; Kettles; African Americans; Women domestics; Houses; Women
